title: 105_hr3497
content: The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" establishes individual investment accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to individual investment accounts established for their benefit. An individual investment account is a trust in the U.S. exclusively for an individual, with specific requirements for contributions and trustee qualifications. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to individual investment accounts established for their benefit. Contributions to the trust must comply with specific requirements, including no investment in collectibles and no commingling of assets. Contributions are deemed made on the last day of the taxable year if made before the deadline for filing the tax return. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows deductions for cash payments to individual investment accounts. Contributions must meet specific requirements, and are considered made on the last day of the taxable year if done before the tax return deadline. Distributions from these accounts are taxable unless used for a qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows deductions for cash payments to individual investment accounts. Distributions can be made for qualified 1st-time homebuyer expenses up to $20,000. Additionally, the basis of the home purchased with these funds is reduced by the distribution amount. The transfer of an individual's interest in an individual investment account to a former spouse under a divorce decree is not considered a taxable transfer. The account will be treated as belonging to the spouse post-transfer. Individual investment accounts are exempt from taxation unless specified otherwise. An individual investment account is exempt from taxation unless the account engages in prohibited transactions, leading to loss of tax exemption. If an individual investment account engages in prohibited transactions under section 4975, it will lose its tax-exempt status and be treated as distributing all its assets on the first day of the taxable year. During a taxable year, if an individual uses their investment account as security for a loan, that portion is considered distributed to them. Rollover contributions are allowed if the amount is paid into another account within 60 days. Cost-of-living adjustments apply for taxable years after 1998. Cost-of-Living Adjustment: The $20,000 amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) increases annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment for taxable years after 1998. Dollar amounts are rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Custodial accounts are treated as trusts for this section. The custodial account shall be treated as a trust if held by a bank or another person meeting specified criteria. The trustee of an individual investment account must report to the Secretary and the account holder. The custodial account trustee must report to the Secretary and the account holder regarding contributions, distributions, and other required matters. Individual investment account contributions are deductible in arriving at adjusted gross income. Individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax. Individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax under the new section inserted after section 2045 in the tax code. "Individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax under section 2046 in the tax code." Individual investment accounts are excluded from the gross estate value and are not subject to estate tax. Additionally, a special rule exempts individuals from tax on prohibited transactions related to these accounts.
